CC   -!- FUNCTION: Actively transports glucose into cells by Na(+)
CC       cotransport with a Na(+) to glucose coupling ratio of 2:1.
CC       Efficient substrate transport in mammalian kidney is provided by
CC       the concerted action of a low affinity high capacity and a high
CC       affinity low capacity Na(+)/glucose cotransporter arranged in
CC       series along kidney proximal tubules.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylation is not necessary for the cotransporter
CC       function. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the sodium:solute symporter (SSF) (TC
CC       2.A.21) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   INDUCTION.
RX   PubMed=11489864; DOI=10.1128/JB.183.17.5110-5121.2001;
RA   Yamamoto H., Serizawa M., Thompson J., Sekiguchi J.;
RT   "Regulation of the glv operon in Bacillus subtilis: YfiA (GlvR) is a

RN   [4]
RP   FUNCTION IN MALTOSE UPTAKE, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL
RP   PROPERTIES, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RC   STRAIN=168;
RX   PubMed=16707683; DOI=10.1128/JB.00213-06;
RA   Schoenert S., Seitz S., Krafft H., Feuerbaum E.-A., Andernach I.,
RA   Witz G., Dahl M.K.;
RT   "Maltose and maltodextrin utilization by Bacillus subtilis.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 188:3911-3922(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. This system is involved in maltose transport.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16707683}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: [Protein]-N(pi)-phospho-L-histidine +
CC       maltose(Side 1) = [protein]-L-histidine + maltose 6'-
CC       phosphate(Side 2). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16707683}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=5 uM for maltose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16707683};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00426}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By maltose; repressed by glucose.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11489864}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC domain type-1 forms the PTS system translocation
CC       channel and contains the specific substrate-binding site.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PTS EIIB type-1 domain is phosphorylated by phospho-
CC       EIIA on a cysteinyl residue. Then, it transfers the phosphoryl
CC       group to the sugar substrate concomitantly with the sugar uptake
CC       processed by the PTS EIIC type-1 domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00421}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Cells lacking this gene show no maltose
CC       uptake. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16707683}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Maltose uptake in B.subtilis occurs only via the
CC       malP-encoded specific PTS-dependent EIICB(Mal) and not via another
CC       transport mechanism. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:16707683}.

RP   TOPOLOGY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   STRAIN=K12 / MG1655 / ATCC 47076;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane (PubMed:14645248, PubMed:9063979). This system is
CC       involved in mannosyl-D-glycerate transport (PubMed:14645248). Also
CC       involved in thermoinduction of ompC (PubMed:9063979).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14645248, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9063979}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: [Protein]-N(pi)-phospho-L-histidine + 2-O-
CC       alpha-mannosyl-D-glycerate (Side 1) = [protein]-L-histidine + 2-O-
CC       (6-phospho-alpha-D-mannosyl)-D-glycerate (Side 2).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14645248}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=10 uM for mannosyl-D-glycerate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14645248};
CC         Vmax=0.65 nmol/min/mg enzyme for mannosyl-D-glycerate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14645248};
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P0ACA3:sspA; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-558542, EBI-558482;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00427, ECO:0000305|PubMed:14645248}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00427,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:14645248}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Induced by mannosyl-D-glycerate. Repressed by MngR.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14645248}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PTS EIIA type-2 domain is phosphorylated by phospho-
CC       HPr on a histidyl residue. Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group
CC       to the PTS EIIB type-2 domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00417}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PTS EIIB type-2 domain is phosphorylated by phospho-
CC       EIIA on a cysteinyl residue. Then, it transfers the phosphoryl
CC       group to the sugar substrate concomitantly with the sugar uptake
CC       processed by the PTS EIIC type-2 domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00422}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC type-2 domain forms the PTS system translocation
CC       channel and contains the specific substrate-binding site.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00427}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Cells lacking this gene are unable to
CC       transport mannosyl-D-glycerate. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14645248}.

RT   proteome.";
RL   Science 308:1321-1323(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitant with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. The enzyme II complex composed of SrlA, SrlB and SrlE is
CC       involved in glucitol/sorbitol transport. It can also use D-
CC       mannitol. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1100608}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00430, ECO:0000305|PubMed:3553176}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00430,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:3553176}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Regulated by an unusual system which consists of the
CC       activator GutM and the repressor GutR in addition to the cAMP-CRP
CC       complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:3062173}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC domain forms the PTS system translocation channel
CC       and contains the specific substrate-binding site.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00430}.

RP   TOPOLOGY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   STRAIN=K12 / MG1655 / ATCC 47076;
RX   PubMed=15919996; DOI=10.1126/science.1109730;
RA   Daley D.O., Rapp M., Granseth E., Melen K., Drew D., von Heijne G.;
RT   "Global topology analysis of the Escherichia coli inner membrane
RT   proteome.";
RL   Science 308:1321-1323(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. The enzyme II complex composed of SrlA, SrlB and SrlE is
CC       involved in glucitol/sorbitol transport. It can also use D-
CC       mannitol. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1100608}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: [Protein]-N(pi)-phospho-L-histidine + D-
CC       sorbitol(Side 1) = [protein]-L-histidine + D-sorbitol 6-
CC       phosphate(Side 2). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1100608}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=44 uM for D-glucitol {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1100608};
CC         KM=60 uM for D-mannitol {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1100608};
CC         Vmax=7.2 nmol/min/mg enzyme with D-mannitol as substrate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1100608};
CC         Vmax=0.83 nmol/min/mg enzyme with D-glucitol as substrate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1100608};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:3553176}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255, ECO:0000305|PubMed:3553176}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Regulated by an unusual system which consists of the
CC       activator GutM and the repressor GutR in addition to the cAMP-CRP
CC       complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:3062173}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIB domain is phosphorylated by phospho-EIIA on a
CC       cysteinyl or histidyl residue, depending on the transported sugar.
CC       Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group to the sugar substrate
CC       concomitantly with the sugar uptake processed by the EIIC domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00425}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. The enzyme II complex composed of PtsG and Crr is
CC       involved in glucose transport. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P69786}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: [Protein]-N(pi)-phospho-L-histidine + D-
CC       glucose(Side 1) = [protein]-L-histidine + D-glucose 6-
CC       phosphate(Side 2). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P69786}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00426}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIB domain is phosphorylated by phospho-EIIA on a
CC       cysteinyl or histidyl residue, depending on the transported sugar.
CC       Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group to the sugar substrate
CC       concomitantly with the sugar uptake processed by the EIIC domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00421}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC domain forms the PTS system translocation channel
CC       and contains the specific substrate-binding site.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Facilitative glucose transporter. This isoform likely
CC       mediates the bidirectional transfer of glucose across the plasma
CC       membrane of hepatocytes and is responsible for uptake of glucose
CC       by the beta cells; may comprise part of the glucose-sensing
CC       mechanism of the beta cell. May also participate with the
CC       Na(+)/glucose cotransporter in the transcellular transport of
CC       glucose in the small intestine and kidney (By similarity).

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       -transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIB domain is phosphorylated by phospho-EIIA on a
CC       cysteinyl or histidyl residue, depending on the transported sugar.
CC       Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group to the sugar substrate
CC       concomitantly with the sugar uptake processed by the EIIC domain.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitant with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. The enzyme II complex composed of GatA, GatB and GatC is
CC       involved in galactitol transport. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P69831}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a complex with one each of subunit of GatA, GatB
CC       and 2 subunits of GatC. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P69831}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00427}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00427}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Constitutively expressed.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P69831}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC domain forms the PTS system translocation channel
CC       and contains the specific substrate-binding site.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00427}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Outer membrane channel protein allowing the entry of N-
CC       acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac, the most abundant sialic acid on
CC       host cell surfaces) into the bacteria. NanC proteins form high-
CC       conductance channels which are open at low membrane potentials and
CC       which have a weak anion selectivity (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell outer membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the oligogalacturonate-specific porin KdgM
CC       (TC 1.B.35) family. NanC subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAG59493.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=BAB38693.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. This system is involved in fructose transport.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P20966, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P47308}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: [Protein]-N(pi)-phospho-L-histidine + D-
CC       fructose(Side 1) = [protein]-L-histidine + D-fructose 1-
CC       phosphate(Side 2). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P20966}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       O34755:ykoT; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-5242378, EBI-5242987;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00427}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00427}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PTS EIIA type-2 domain is phosphorylated by phospho-
CC       HPr on a histidyl residue. Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group
CC       to the PTS EIIB type-2 domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00417}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PTS EIIB type-2 domain is phosphorylated by phospho-
CC       EIIA on a cysteinyl residue. Then, it transfers the phosphoryl
CC       group to the sugar substrate concomitantly with the sugar uptake
CC       processed by the PTS EIIC type-2 domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00422}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC type-2 domain forms the PTS system translocation
CC       channel and contains the specific substrate-binding site.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00427}.

RP   FUNCTION IN ANHMURNAC UPTAKE.
RX   PubMed=16452451; DOI=10.1128/JB.188.4.1660-1662.2006;
RA   Uehara T., Suefuji K., Jaeger T., Mayer C., Park J.T.;
RT   "MurQ etherase is required by Escherichia coli in order to metabolize
RT   anhydro-N-acetylmuramic acid obtained either from the environment or
RT   from its own cell wall.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 188:1660-1662(2006).
RN   [7]
RP   INDUCTION.
RC   STRAIN=K12 / MG1655 / ATCC 47076;
RX   PubMed=18723630; DOI=10.1128/JB.00642-08;
RA   Jaeger T., Mayer C.;
RT   "The transcriptional factors MurR and catabolite activator protein
RT   regulate N-acetylmuramic acid catabolism in Escherichia coli.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 190:6598-6608(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. This system is involved in N-acetylmuramic acid (MurNAc)
CC       transport, yielding cytoplasmic MurNAc-6-P. Is responsible for
CC       growth on MurNAc as the sole source of carbon and energy. Is also
CC       able to take up anhydro-N-acetylmuramic acid (anhMurNAc), but
CC       cannot phosphorylate the carbon 6, probably because of the 1,6-
CC       anhydro ring. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15060041,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16452451}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: [Protein]-N(pi)-phospho-L-histidine + N-
CC       acetylmuramate(Side 1) = [protein]-L-histidine + N-acetylmuramate
CC       6-phosphate(Side 2). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15060041}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00426}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Induced by MurNAc 6-phosphate that releases the
CC       repressor MurR from the DNA. Also up-regulated by the cAMP
CC       receptor protein crp via the binding of crp-cAMP to a class I site
CC       upstream of the murQ promoter. Repressed by MurR in the absence of
CC       MurNAc 6-phosphate. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18723630}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIB domain is phosphorylated by phospho-EIIA on a
CC       cysteinyl or histidyl residue, depending on the transported sugar.
CC       Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group to the sugar substrate
CC       concomitantly with the sugar uptake processed by the EIIC domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00421}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC domain forms the PTS system translocation channel
CC       and contains the specific substrate-binding site.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The PTS domain EIIA required for activity was shown
CC       to be the crr-encoded enzyme IIA-glucose, EIIA-Glc.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Transports nucleotide sugars from the cytosol into Golgi
CC       vesicles where glycosyltransferases function.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with SLC35A3. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23089177}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q9Y2D2:SLC35A3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8101118, EBI-3917581;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=UGT2;
CC         IsoId=P78381-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=UGT1;
CC         IsoId=P78381-2; Sequence=VSP_003728;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=P78381-3; Sequence=VSP_042029;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=P78381-4; Sequence=VSP_054335, VSP_003728;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=P78381-5; Sequence=VSP_055197, VSP_003728;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- DISEASE: Congenital disorder of glycosylation 2M (CDG2M)
CC       [MIM:300896]: A disorder characterized by developmental delay,
CC       hypotonia, ocular anomalies, and brain malformations. Othere more
CC       variable clinical features included seizures, hypsarrhythmia, poor
CC       feeding, microcephaly, recurrent infections, dysmorphic features,
CC       shortened limbs, and coagulation defects. Congenital disorders of
CC       glycosylation are caused by a defect in glycoprotein biosynthesis
CC       and characterized by under-glycosylated serum glycoproteins and a
CC       wide variety of clinical features. The broad spectrum of features
CC       reflects the critical role of N-glycoproteins during embryonic
CC       development, differentiation, and maintenance of cell functions.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23561849, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24115232}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the nucleotide-sugar transporter family.
CC       SLC35A subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Transports CMP-sialic acid from the cytosol into Golgi
CC       vesicles where glycosyltransferases function.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P78382-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P78382-2; Sequence=VSP_042916;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- DISEASE: Congenital disorder of glycosylation 2F (CDG2F)
CC       [MIM:603585]: CDGs are a family of severe inherited diseases
CC       caused by a defect in protein N-glycosylation. They are
CC       characterized by under-glycosylated serum proteins. These
CC       multisystem disorders present with a wide variety of clinical
CC       features, such as disorders of the nervous system development,
CC       psychomotor retardation, dysmorphic features, hypotonia,
CC       coagulation disorders, and immunodeficiency. The broad spectrum of
CC       features reflects the critical role of N-glycoproteins during
CC       embryonic development, differentiation, and maintenance of cell
CC       functions. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15576474}. Note=The disease is
CC       caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the nucleotide-sugar transporter family.
CC       SLC35A subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the binding-protein-dependent transport system
CC       for L-arabinose. Probably responsible for the translocation of the
CC       substrate across the membrane.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Transcription is repressed by glucose and by the
CC       binding of AraR to the operon promoter. L-arabinose acts as an
CC       inducer by inhibiting the binding of AraR to the DNA, thus
CC       allowing expression of the gene. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10417639}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the binding-protein-dependent transport
CC       system permease family. MalFG subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=18177889; DOI=10.1016/j.jmb.2007.12.015;

RT   "Substrate selectivity of the melibiose permease (MelY) from
RT   Enterobacter cloacae.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 376:681-693(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Responsible for transport of melibiose into the cell,
CC       with the concomitant import of a proton (symport system)
CC       (PubMed:9209070, PubMed:9375783, PubMed:12775706,
CC       PubMed:18177889). Can also transport lactose, and has weak
CC       activity with maltose (PubMed:18177889, PubMed:12775706). Cannot
CC       transport the analog methyl-1-thio-beta,D-galactopyranoside (TMG)
CC       (PubMed:18177889). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12775706,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18177889, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9209070,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9375783}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=0.26 mM for melibiose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18177889};
CC         KM=0.51 mM for lactose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18177889};
CC         KM=14 mM for maltose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12775706};
CC         Vmax=82 nmol/min/mg enzyme with melibiose as substrate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18177889};
CC         Vmax=54 nmol/min/mg enzyme with lactose as substrate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18177889};
CC         Vmax=121 nmol/min/mg enzyme with maltose as substrate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12775706};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily.
CC       Oligosaccharide:H(+) symporter (OHS) (TC 2.A.1.5) family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Uptake of arabinose across the boundary membrane with
CC       the concomitant transport of protons into the cell (symport
CC       system). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9401028}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Transcription is repressed by the binding of AraR to
CC       the promoter. L-arabinose acts as an inducer by inhibiting the
CC       binding of AraR to the DNA, thus allowing expression of the gene.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10417639}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily. Sugar
CC       transporter (TC 2.A.1.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

OC   Bacteria; Firmicutes; Bacilli; Lactobacillales; Lactobacillaceae;
OC   Lactobacillus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=1589;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA], FUNCTION, INDUCTION, AND DISRUPTION
RP   PHENOTYPE.
RC   STRAIN=MD353;
RX   PubMed=9573180;
RA   Chaillou S., Lokman B.C., Leer R.J., Posthuma C., Postma P.W.,
RA   Pouwels P.H.;
RT   "Cloning, sequence analysis, and characterization of the genes

RL   J. Bacteriol. 180:2312-2320(1998).
RN   [2]
RP   SEQUENCE REVISION.
RA   Chaillou S., Lokman B.C., Leer R.J., Posthuma C., Postma P.W.,
RA   Pouwels P.H.;
RL   Submitted (OCT-1998) to the EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ databases.
RN   [3]
RP   FUNCTION AS A SYMPORTER.
RX   PubMed=9683504;
RA   Chaillou S., Postma P.W., Pouwels P.H.;
RT   "Functional expression in Lactobacillus plantarum of xylP encoding the
RT   isoprimeverose transporter of Lactobacillus pentosus.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 180:4011-4014(1998).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the metabolism of isoprimeverose
CC       (PubMed:9573180, PubMed:9683504). Transports isoprimeverose into
CC       the cell. Transport is driven by the proton motive force generated
CC       by malolactic fermentation. Cannot transport D-xylose
CC       (PubMed:9683504). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9573180,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9683504}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression is negatively regulated by XylR and is
CC       subject to CcpA-dependent catabolite repression.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9573180}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: XylP-xylQ double mutant retains the ability
CC       to ferment xylose but is impaired in its ability to ferment
CC       isoprimeverose. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9573180}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the sodium:galactoside symporter (TC 2.A.2)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

AC   P9WG00; F2GFS5; L0T918; O50453; Q7D8J7;

DT   25-OCT-2017, entry version 23.
DE   RecName: Full=Trehalose transport system permease protein SugB;
GN   Name=sugB; OrderedLocusNames=MT1275;
OS   Mycobacterium tuberculosis (strain CDC 1551 / Oshkosh).
OC   Bacteria; Actinobacteria; Corynebacteriales; Mycobacteriaceae;
OC   Mycobacterium; Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=83331;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].
RC   STRAIN=CDC 1551 / Oshkosh;
RX   PubMed=12218036; DOI=10.1128/JB.184.19.5479-5490.2002;
RA   Fleischmann R.D., Alland D., Eisen J.A., Carpenter L., White O.,
RA   Peterson J.D., DeBoy R.T., Dodson R.J., Gwinn M.L., Haft D.H.,
RA   Hickey E.K., Kolonay J.F., Nelson W.C., Umayam L.A., Ermolaeva M.D.,
RA   Salzberg S.L., Delcher A., Utterback T.R., Weidman J.F., Khouri H.M.,
RA   Gill J., Mikula A., Bishai W., Jacobs W.R. Jr., Venter J.C.,
RA   Fraser C.M.;
RT   "Whole-genome comparison of Mycobacterium tuberculosis clinical and
RT   laboratory strains.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 184:5479-5490(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the ABC transporter complex LpqY-SugA-SugB-SugC,
CC       which is highly specific for uptake of trehalose. Involved in the
CC       recycling of extracellular trehalose released from trehalose-
CC       containing molecules synthesized by M.tuberculosis. Trehalose
CC       uptake is essential for virulence. Probably responsible for the
CC       translocation of the substrate across the membrane (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The complex is composed of two ATP-binding proteins
CC       (SugC), two transmembrane proteins (Suga and SugB) and a solute-
CC       binding protein (LpqY). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00441}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the binding-protein-dependent transport
CC       system permease family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

ID   MELB_KLEPN              Reviewed;         471 AA.
AC   Q02581;
DT   01-JUL-1993, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   01-JUL-1993, sequence version 1.
DT   22-NOV-2017, entry version 85.
DE   RecName: Full=Melibiose carrier protein;
DE   AltName: Full=Melibiose permease;
DE   AltName: Full=Melibiose transporter;
DE   AltName: Full=Na+ (Li+)/melibiose symporter;
DE   AltName: Full=Thiomethylgalactoside permease II;
GN   Name=melB;
OS   Klebsiella pneumoniae.
OC   Bacteria; Proteobacteria; Gammaproteobacteria; Enterobacterales;
OC   Enterobacteriaceae; Klebsiella.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=573;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA].
RC   STRAIN=2002;
RX   PubMed=1339436;
RA   Hama H., Wilson T.H.;
RT   "Primary structure and characteristics of the melibiose carrier of
RT   Klebsiella pneumoniae.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 267:18371-18376(1992).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Responsible for melibiose transport. It is capable of
CC       using hydrogen and lithium cations as coupling cations for
CC       cotransport, depending on the particular sugar transported
CC       (symport system). It catalyzes hydrogen cation-melibiose, lithium
CC       cation-lactose, and hydrogen/lithium cations-methyl-1-thio-beta-D-
CC       galactopyranoside (TMG) cotransport. This protein seems to be
CC       lacking the ability to recognize sodium cations.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the sodium:galactoside symporter (TC 2.A.2)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Facilitative glucose transporter that can also mediate
CC       the uptake of various other monosaccharides across the cell
CC       membrane. Mediates the uptake of glucose, 2-deoxyglucose,
CC       galactose, mannose, xylose and fucose, and probably also
CC       dehydroascorbate. Does not mediate fructose transport.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11169}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11169}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11169}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Brain and osteoblastic cells (at protein
CC       level) (PubMed:21076856). Highly expressed in brain
CC       (PubMed:7475896, PubMed:21076856). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21076856,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7475896}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Transport is mediated via a series of conformation
CC       changes, switching between a conformation where the substrate-
CC       binding cavity is accessible from the outside, and a another
CC       conformation where it is accessible from the cytoplasm.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11169}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily. Sugar
CC       transporter (TC 2.A.1.1) family. Glucose transporter subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES, AND INDUCTION.
RX   PubMed=18506478; DOI=10.1007/s00425-008-0755-8;
RA   Wang Y., Xiao Y., Zhang Y., Chai C., Wei G., Wei X., Xu H., Wang M.,
RA   Ouwerkerk P.B., Zhu Z.;
RT   "Molecular cloning, functional characterization and expression
RT   analysis of a novel monosaccharide transporter gene OsMST6 from rice
RT   (Oryza sativa L.).";
RL   Planta 228:525-535(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates active uptake of hexoses by sugar:proton
CC       symport (Probable). Can transport glucose, fructose, mannose and
CC       galactose (PubMed:17874189, PubMed:18506478). Can transport xylose
CC       and ribose (PubMed:18506478). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17874189,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478, ECO:0000305|PubMed:17874189}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=209.2 uM for glucose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC         KM=271.1 uM for fructose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC         KM=102.4 uM for mannose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC         KM=95 uM for galactose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC         KM=142.4 uM for ribose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC         KM=135.2 uM for xylose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000255}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in roots, shoots, leaf blades, leaf
CC       sheaths, anthers, ovaries and embryos.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17874189}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Induced by glucose, sucrose and salt stress.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily. Sugar
CC       transporter (TC 2.A.1.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=20603282; DOI=10.1093/jxb/erq175;
RA   Hirose T., Zhang Z., Miyao A., Hirochika H., Ohsugi R., Terao T.;
RT   "Disruption of a gene for rice sucrose transporter, OsSUT1, impairs
RT   pollen function but pollen maturation is unaffected.";
RL   J. Exp. Bot. 61:3639-3646(2010).
RN   [10]
RP   FUNCTION, AND BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES.
RX   PubMed=19965875; DOI=10.1093/pcp/pcp172;
RA   Sun Y., Reinders A., LaFleur K.R., Mori T., Ward J.M.;
RT   "Transport activity of rice sucrose transporters OsSUT1 and OsSUT5.";
RL   Plant Cell Physiol. 51:114-122(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Responsible for the transport of sucrose into the cell,
CC       with the concomitant uptake of protons (symport system). Can also
CC       transport other glucosides such as maltose, salicin, helicin, and
CC       alpha-phenylglucoside. Probably required for apoplastic phloem
CC       sucrose loading in source tissues (e.g. leaves) in order to
CC       transport it to sink tissues (e.g. roots, flowers). Probably not
CC       involved in transport of sugars across the symplastic
CC       discontinuity between the endosperm and the embryo. Essential for
CC       normal pollen germination, but not for pollen maturation or starch
CC       accumulation in pollen. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19965875,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20603282, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9522469}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=7.5 mM for sucrose (at pH 5.6) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19965875};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 5. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19965875};
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Glycan biosynthesis; sucrose metabolism.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q10R54-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q10R54-2; Sequence=VSP_039741;
CC         Note=Derived from EST data. No experimental confirmation
CC         available.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q10R54-3; Sequence=VSP_039742, VSP_039743;
CC         Note=Derived from EST data. No experimental confirmation
CC         available.;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q10R54-4; Sequence=VSP_039739, VSP_039740;
CC         Note=Derived from EST data. No experimental confirmation
CC         available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widely expressed. Highly expressed in embryo,
CC       endosperm, germinating seeds, source leaf sheaths and panicles,
CC       but at very low levels in roots. Expressed in phloem companion
CC       cells. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10982424, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12668768,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9522469}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed in developing caryopses from 3 days
CC       after flowering (DAF), increases to a maximal level at 5 to 7 DAF,
CC       and then gradually declines to a barely detectable level by 20 DAF
CC       when grain filling stage nearly terminates. Expressed in
CC       developing pollen and anther walls from 5 to 1 day before
CC       anthesis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12668768,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20603282}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By exogenous sugar supply. Down-regulated by sugar
CC       starvation and light in dark-grown seedlings.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10982424, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9522469}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Male sterility probably due to impaired
CC       pollen germination. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20603282}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycoside-pentoside-hexuronide (GPH)
CC       cation symporter transporter (TC 2.A.2.4) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May be involved in specific transport of UDP-Gal from
CC       the cytosol to the Golgi lumen. Involved in the maintenance of
CC       optimal conditions for the folding of secretory pathway proteins
CC       in the endoplasmic reticulum. Overexpression confers resistance to
CC       the immunosuppressive drug, leflunomide.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11284009, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11284010,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11391470}.

CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11284010}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11284010}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the nucleotide-sugar transporter family.
CC       SLC35B subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

ID   S35D2_PIG               Reviewed;         343 AA.
AC   Q15B89;
DT   15-JAN-2008, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   25-JUL-2006, sequence version 1.
DT   27-SEP-2017, entry version 43.
DE   RecName: Full=UDP-N-acetylglucosamine/UDP-glucose/GDP-mannose transporter;
DE   AltName: Full=Solute carrier family 35 member D2;
DE   Flags: Fragment;
GN   Name=SLC35D2;
OS   Sus scrofa (Pig).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Mammalia; Eutheria; Laurasiatheria; Cetartiodactyla; Suina; Suidae;
OC   Sus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=9823;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA].
RX   PubMed=16978188; DOI=10.1111/j.1365-2052.2006.01499.x;
RA   Kim J.H., Lim H.T., Park E.W., Ovilo C., Lee J.H., Jeon J.T.;
RT   "A gene-based radiation hybrid map of the pig chromosome 6q32 region
RT   associated with a QTL for fat deposition traits.";
RL   Anim. Genet. 37:522-523(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Antiporter transporting nucleotide sugars such as UDP-N-
CC       acetylglucosamine (UDP-GlcNAc), UDP-glucose (UDP-Glc) and GDP-
CC       mannose (GDP-Man) pooled in the cytosol into the lumen of the
CC       Golgi in exchange for the corresponding nucleosides monophosphates
CC       (UMP for UDP-sugars and GMP for GDP-sugars). May take part in
CC       heparan sulfate synthesis by supplying UDP-Glc-NAc, the donor
CC       substrate, and thus be involved in growth factor signaling (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane {ECO:0000250};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TPT transporter family. SLC35D
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION.
RC   STRAIN=cv. IR24;
RX   PubMed=11606550;
RA   Li Z.-K., Sanchez A., Angeles E., Singh S., Domingo J., Huang N.,
RA   Khush G.S.;
RT   "Are the dominant and recessive plant disease resistance genes
RT   similar? A case study of rice R genes and Xanthomonas oryzae pv.
RT   oryzae races.";
RL   Genetics 159:757-765(2001).
RN   [4]
RP   FUNCTION, INDUCTION BY XANTHOMONAS ORYZAE, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RC   STRAIN=cv. IR24, and cv. IRBB13;
RX   PubMed=16798873; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0604088103;
RA   Yang B., Sugio A., White F.F.;
RT   "Os8N3 is a host disease-susceptibility gene for bacterial blight of
RT   rice.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 103:10503-10508(2006).
RN   [5]
RP   INDUCTION BY PTHXO1.
RC   STRAIN=cv. IR24, and cv. IRBB13;
RX   PubMed=20345643; DOI=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2010.03217.x;
RA   Roemer P., Recht S., Strauss T., Elsaesser J., Schornack S., Boch J.,
RA   Wang S., Lahaye T.;
RT   "Promoter elements of rice susceptibility genes are bound and
RT   activated by specific TAL effectors from the bacterial blight
RT   pathogen, Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae.";
RL   New Phytol. 187:1048-1057(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates both low-affinity uptake and efflux of sugar
CC       across the plasma membrane (By similarity). Required for pollen
CC       viability. Confers sensitivity to bacterial blight mediated by
CC       X.oryzae pv. oryzae (Xoo) in its Xa13 allelic form (e.g. cv.
CC       IR24), probably by providing the sugar required for the pathogen
CC       growth. However, a recessive resistance can be associated with the
CC       xa13 allele (in which the promoter is mutated leading to reduced
CC       induction upon pathogen infection, e.g. cv. IRBB13), specifically
CC       toward Xoo Philippine race 6 and Indian race PXO8
CC       (PubMed:11606550, PubMed:16648463, PubMed:16798873).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8L9J7, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11606550,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16648463, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16798873}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms homooligomers and/or heterooligomers.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8L9J7}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8L9J7}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8L9J7}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Mostly expressed in panicles and anthers. Also
CC       detected at low levels in leaves and roots.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16648463, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16798873}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Accumulates to high levels in pollen grains,
CC       tapetal cells, and middle-layer cells of the anther wall. Also
CC       detected at high levels in connective tissue cells and the
CC       connective vascular element at the unicellular- to-bicellular
CC       pollen grain stages. At the tricellular pollen grain stage,
CC       confined to the cells of connective vascular elements.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16648463}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By the X.oryzae pv. oryzae (Xoo) transcription
CC       activator-like effector (TALe) protein pthXo1 and, possibly,
CC       AvrXa7. The induction by X.oryzae pv. oryzae (Xoo) PXO99 occurs
CC       only in the Xa13 allelic form that contains full promoter region.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16648463, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16798873,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20345643}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SWEET sugar transporter family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA], AND PROBABLE FUNCTION.
RC   STRAIN=ATCC 29145 / Sp7 / DSM 1690 / IMET 11303;
RX   PubMed=16950779; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M606727200;
RA   Watanabe S., Shimada N., Tajima K., Kodaki T., Makino K.;
RT   "Identification and characterization of L-arabonate dehydratase, L-2-
RT   keto-3-deoxyarabonate dehydratase and L-arabinolactonase involved in
RT   an alternative pathway of L-arabinose metabolism: novel evolutionary
RT   insight into sugar metabolism.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 281:33521-33536(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the ABC transporter complex AraFGH involved in
CC       L-arabinose import. Responsible for the translocation of the
CC       substrate across the membrane (Probable). {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The complex is composed of two ATP-binding proteins
CC       (AraG), two transmembrane proteins (AraH) and a solute-binding
CC       protein (AraF). {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the binding-protein-dependent transport
CC       system permease family. AraH/RbsC subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in beta-(1-->2)glucan export. Its export to the
CC       periplasmic space is required to exert its action as a virulence
CC       factor. Transmembrane domains (TMD) form a pore in the inner
CC       membrane and the ATP-binding domain (NBD) is responsible for
CC       energy generation (Probable). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:15039351}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + H(2)O + beta-glucan(In) = ADP +
CC       phosphate + beta-glucan(Out). {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_01728}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_01728}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q2YNV7:BAB1_0108; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-11509336, EBI-11509311;
CC       Q2YRC8:BAB1_1718; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11509336, EBI-11509356;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_01728, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15039351}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_01728,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15039351}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: In NdvA the ATP-binding domain (NBD) and the transmembrane
CC       domain (TMD) are fused.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ABC transporter superfamily. Beta-
CC       (1-->2)glucan exporter (TC 3.A.1.108.1) family.

RC   TISSUE=Seedling;
RX   PubMed=17586839; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M700164-MCP200;
RA   Niittylae T., Fuglsang A.T., Palmgren M.G., Frommer W.B.,

RN   [11]
RP   FUNCTION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, INDUCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=18359840; DOI=10.1104/pp.108.118992;
RA   Sivitz A.B., Reinders A., Ward J.M.;
RT   "Arabidopsis sucrose transporter AtSUC1 is important for pollen
RT   germination and sucrose-induced anthocyanin accumulation.";
RL   Plant Physiol. 147:92-100(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Responsible for the transport of sucrose into the cell,
CC       with the concomitant uptake of protons (symport system). This
CC       transport is both voltage- and energy-dependent. Can also
CC       transport other glucosides such as maltose, alpha-phenylglucoside
CC       and beta-phenylglucoside. May also transport biotin. Required for
CC       normal pollen germination and anthocyanin accumulation induced by
CC       sucrose. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10476074,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18359840, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7920705,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9307438}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by DEPC, protonophores (e.g.
CC       dinitrophenol and carbonyl cyanide m-chlorophenyl-hydrazone
CC       (CCCP)), and SH group inhibitors (e.g. N-ethylmaleimide (NEM) and
CC       p-chloromercuriphenyl sulphonic acid (PCMPS)).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7920705, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9671798}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=450 uM for sucrose (at pH 5.5 and 30 degrees Celsius)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7920705, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9671798};
CC         Vmax=45 umol/h/g enzyme (without glucose)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7920705, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9671798};
CC         Vmax=154 umol/h/g enzyme (in the presence of 10 mM glucose)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7920705, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9671798};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 5-6. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7920705,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:9671798};
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Glycan biosynthesis; sucrose metabolism.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000255}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in flowers (at protein level).
CC       Highly expressed in pollen. Expressed in pollen tubes and root
CC       vascular cylinder, pericycle and endodermis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10476074, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18359840}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Transcripts accumulate in mature pollen
CC       before and during germination, but translation starts only when
CC       pollen germination initiates, and continues in pollen tubes.
CC       Expressed in cells surrounding the vascular bundle of the anther
CC       connective tissue, mostly at the dehiscence time. Also present in
CC       a ring of parenchymatic cells between the xylem vessels of the
CC       style (upper end of the transmitting tract toward which pollen
CC       tubes grow). Expressed in the epidermal cell layers of funiculi
CC       (at protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10476074}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By exogenous sucrose in roots. Induced by sucrose
CC       depletion. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11673631,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18359840}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Defective pollen with low rate of
CC       germination. Reduction of anthocyanin accumulation in response to
CC       exogenous sucrose or maltose. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18359840}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycoside-pentoside-hexuronide (GPH)
CC       cation symporter transporter (TC 2.A.2.4) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       -transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00426}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIB domain is phosphorylated by phospho-EIIA on a
CC       cysteinyl or histidyl residue, depending on the transported sugar.
CC       Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group to the sugar substrate
CC       concomitantly with the sugar uptake processed by the EIIC domain.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC domain forms the PTS system translocation channel
CC       and contains the specific substrate-binding site.

RA   Ditty J.L., Harwood C.S.;
RT   "Charged amino acids conserved in the aromatic acid/H+ symporter

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Transports 4-hydroxybenzoate (4-HBA) and protocatechuate
CC       across the membrane. Driven by the proton motive force. Functions
CC       also as a chemoreceptor, which is required for chemotaxis to
CC       aromatic acids. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7961399,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9260946}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=6 uM for 4-hydroxybenzoate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9260946};
CC         Vmax=25 nmol/min/mg enzyme with 4-hydroxybenzoate as substrate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9260946};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10438780, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9260946}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10438780,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9260946}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Amino acids located between the second and third, and the
CC       eighth and ninth transmembrane regions are required for substrate
CC       transport. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10438780}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily. Aromatic
CC       acid:H(+) symporter (AAHS) (TC 2.A.1.15) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF N-TERMINUS, FUNCTION, SUBSTRATE SPECIFICITY,
RP   ENZYME REGULATION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL
RP   PROPERTIES.
RX   PubMed=10537210;
RA   Christiansen I., Hengstenberg W.;
RT   "Staphylococcal phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent phosphotransferase
RT   system -- two highly similar glucose permeases in Staphylococcus
RT   carnosus with different glucoside specificity: protein engineering in
RT   vivo?";
RL   Microbiology 145:2881-2889(1999).
RN   [4]
RP   INDUCTION BY GLCT.
RX   PubMed=10974121; DOI=10.1099/00221287-146-9-2333;
RA   Knezevic I., Bachem S., Sickmann A., Meyer H.E., Stuelke J.,
RA   Hengstenberg W.;
RT   "Regulation of the glucose-specific phosphotransferase system (PTS) of
RT   Staphylococcus carnosus by the antiterminator protein GlcT.";
RL   Microbiology 146:2333-2342(2000).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       -transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. This system is involved in alpha- and beta-glucoside
CC       transport. Can also transport glucose, but not galactose,
CC       fructose, mannose, cellobiose, sucrose, maltose, lactose,
CC       melibiose and trehalose, as well as N-acetylglucosamine.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by methyl alpha-D-glucoside, methyl
CC       beta-D-glucoside, p-nitrophenyl alpha-D-glucoside, o-nitrophenyl
CC       beta-D-glucoside and salicin, but not by 2-deoxyglucose.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=19 uM for glucose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210};
CC         KM=37.2 uM for glucose (in the presence of Triton X-100)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00426, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated by the antiterminator protein GlcT.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10974121}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC domain forms the PTS system translocation channel
CC       and contains the specific substrate-binding site.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIB domain is phosphorylated by phospho-EIIA on a
CC       cysteinyl or histidyl residue, depending on the transported sugar.
CC       Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group to the sugar substrate
CC       concomitantly with the sugar uptake processed by the EIIC domain.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIA domain is phosphorylated by phospho-HPr on a
CC       histidyl residue. Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group to the
CC       EIIB domain.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RN   [3]
RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF N-TERMINUS, FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY,
RP   SUBSTRATE SPECIFICITY, ENZYME REGULATION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND
RP   BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES.
RX   PubMed=10537210;
RA   Christiansen I., Hengstenberg W.;
RT   "Staphylococcal phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent phosphotransferase
RT   system -- two highly similar glucose permeases in Staphylococcus
RT   carnosus with different glucoside specificity: protein engineering in
RT   vivo?";
RL   Microbiology 145:2881-2889(1999).
RN   [4]
RP   INDUCTION BY GLCT.
RX   PubMed=10974121; DOI=10.1099/00221287-146-9-2333;
RA   Knezevic I., Bachem S., Sickmann A., Meyer H.E., Stuelke J.,
RA   Hengstenberg W.;
RT   "Regulation of the glucose-specific phosphotransferase system (PTS) of
RT   Staphylococcus carnosus by the antiterminator protein GlcT.";
RL   Microbiology 146:2333-2342(2000).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. This system is involved in glucose transport. Cannot
CC       transport galactose, fructose, mannose, cellobiose, sucrose,
CC       maltose, lactose, melibiose and trehalose, as well as N-
CC       acetylglucosamine. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: [Protein]-N(pi)-phospho-L-histidine + D-
CC       glucose(Side 1) = [protein]-L-histidine + D-glucose 6-
CC       phosphate(Side 2). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10537210}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by 2-deoxyglucose and methyl beta-D-
CC       glucoside, but not by methyl alpha-D-glucoside, p-nitrophenyl
CC       alpha-D-glucoside, o-nitrophenyl beta-D-glucoside and salicin.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=12 uM for glucose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210};
CC         KM=30.5 uM for glucose (in the presence of Triton X-100)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00426, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10537210}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated by the antiterminator protein GlcT.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10974121}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC domain forms the PTS system translocation channel
CC       and contains the specific substrate-binding site.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIB domain is phosphorylated by phospho-EIIA on a
CC       cysteinyl or histidyl residue, depending on the transported sugar.
CC       Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group to the sugar substrate
CC       concomitantly with the sugar uptake processed by the EIIC domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00421}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIA domain is phosphorylated by phospho-HPr on a
CC       histidyl residue. Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group to the
CC       EIIB domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00416}.

RA   Harhay G.P., Sonstegard T.S., Keele J.W., Heaton M.P., Clawson M.L.,

RT   "Characterization of 954 bovine full-CDS cDNA sequences.";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Inorganic phosphate and glucose-6-phosphate antiporter.
CC       May transport cytoplasmic glucose-6-phosphate into the lumen of
CC       the endoplasmic reticulum and translocate inorganic phosphate into
CC       the opposite direction. Independent of a lumenal glucose-6-
CC       phosphatase. May not play a role in homeostatic regulation of
CC       blood glucose levels. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8TED4}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by vanadate but not by chlorogenic
CC       acid. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8TED4}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8TED4}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily.
CC       Organophosphate:Pi antiporter (OPA) (TC 2.A.1.4) family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Sugar transporter involved in the transport of CMP-
CC       sialic acid from the cytoplasm into the Golgi. May transport
CC       important nucleotide sugars such as CMP-Kdo (2-keto-3-deoxy-D-
CC       manno-octulosonic acid) in physiological conditions.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19822337}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane {ECO:0000305};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in roots, leaves and stalks.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19822337}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the nucleotide-sugar transporter family.
CC       CMP-Sialate:CMP antiporter (TC 2.A.7.12) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       -transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00426}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIB domain is phosphorylated by phospho-EIIA on a
CC       cysteinyl or histidyl residue, depending on the transported sugar.
CC       Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group to the sugar substrate
CC       concomitantly with the sugar uptake processed by the EIIC domain.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC domain forms the PTS system translocation channel
CC       and contains the specific substrate-binding site.

CC       oryzae (PubMed:23879865). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23879865,

RP   REVIEW.
RX   PubMed=25988582; DOI=10.1016/j.pbi.2015.04.005;
RA   Eom J.-S., Chen L.-Q., Sosso D., Julius B.T., Lin I.W., Qu X.-Q.,
RA   Braun D.M., Frommer W.B.;

RT   translocation.";
RL   Curr. Opin. Plant Biol. 25:53-62(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates both low-affinity uptake and efflux of sugar
CC       across the plasma membrane (By similarity). Can transport
CC       galactose. Prevents growth but promotes senescence
CC       (PubMed:25988582, PubMed:24709840). Involved in regulating the
CC       crosstalk between sugar and auxin. Regulates negatively the auxin
CC       signaling pathway and translocation (PubMed:24709840).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8L9J7, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24709840,
CC       ECO:0000303|PubMed:25988582}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms homooligomers and/or heterooligomers.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8L9J7}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24709840};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8L9J7}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Mainly expressed in the floral organs at the
CC       heading stage, and also in stem, root, senescing leaves, stamen,
CC       pistil and hull. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24709840}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SWEET sugar transporter family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC       transporter in the Golgi apparatus. May supply UDP-GlcNAc as

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates active uptake of hexoses by sugar:proton
CC       symport (Probable). Can transport glucose, fructose, mannose,
CC       galactose, xylose and ribose (PubMed:18506478).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478, ECO:0000305|PubMed:18506478}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=266.1 uM for glucose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC         KM=256.9 uM for fructose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC         KM=108.4 uM for mannose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC         KM=48.7 uM for galactose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC         KM=109.6 uM for ribose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC         KM=151 uM for xylose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in leaf blades, leaf sheaths,
CC       anthers, ovaries and embryos. Expressed at low levels in roots and
CC       shoots. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Induced by glucose, sucrose and salt stress.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18506478}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily. Sugar
CC       transporter (TC 2.A.1.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Antiporter transporting nucleotide sugars such as UDP-N-
CC       acetylglucosamine (UDP-GlcNAc), UDP-glucose (UDP-Glc) and GDP-
CC       mannose (GDP-Man) pooled in the cytosol into the lumen of the
CC       Golgi in exchange for the corresponding nucleosides monophosphates
CC       (UMP for UDP-sugars and GMP for GDP-sugars). May take part in
CC       heparan sulfate synthesis by supplying UDP-Glc-NAc, the donor
CC       substrate, and thus be involved in growth factor signaling.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15082721, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15607426}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=8 uM for UDP-N-acetylglucosamine
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15082721};
CC         KM=2.1 uM for UDP-glucose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15082721};
CC         KM=0.14 uM for GDP-mannose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15082721};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15082721, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15607426}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15082721,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15607426}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q76EJ3-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q76EJ3-2; Sequence=VSP_030006;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in heart, kidney, small
CC       intestine, placenta, lung and peripheral blood leukocyte. Weakly
CC       expressed in skeletal muscle and spleen. Not expressed in brain,
CC       colon and thymus. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15607426}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TPT transporter family. SLC35D
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       -transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00426}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00426}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIB domain is phosphorylated by phospho-EIIA on a
CC       cysteinyl or histidyl residue, depending on the transported sugar.
CC       Then, it transfers the phosphoryl group to the sugar substrate
CC       concomitantly with the sugar uptake processed by the EIIC domain.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC domain forms the PTS system translocation channel
CC       and contains the specific substrate-binding site.

RP   BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=20035867; DOI=10.1016/j.ibmb.2009.12.006;
RA   Kanamori Y., Saito Y., Hagiwara-Komoda Y., Tanaka D., Mitsumasu K.,
RA   Kikuta S., Watanabe M., Cornette R., Kikawada T., Okuda T.;
RT   "The trehalose transporter 1 gene sequence is conserved in insects and
RT   encodes proteins with different kinetic properties involved in
RT   trehalose import into peripheral tissues.";
RL   Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 40:30-37(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: High-capacity facilitative transporter for trehalose.
CC       Does not transport maltose, sucrose or lactose. Mediates the
CC       bidirectional transfer of trehalose. Responsible for the transport
CC       of trehalose synthesized in the fat body and the incorporation of
CC       trehalose into other tissues that require a carbon source, thereby
CC       regulating trehalose levels in the hemolymph.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20035867}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=45.74 mM for trehalose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20035867};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20035867};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20035867}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=A {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12364791};
CC         IsoId=Q7PIR5-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=B {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12364791}; Synonyms=C
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12364791};
CC         IsoId=Q7PIR5-2; Sequence=VSP_039518, VSP_039519;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. {ECO:0000305};
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily. Sugar
CC       transporter (TC 2.A.1.1) family. Trehalose transporter subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000255, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20035867}.

RP   INDUCTION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=26423860; DOI=10.1152/ajprenal.00392.2015;

RT   kidney.";
RL   Am. J. Physiol. 309:F916-F924(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: May function as a sodium-dependent glucose transporter
CC       (PubMed:12590146). Potential channels for urea in the inner
CC       medulla of kidney (PubMed:26423860). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12590146,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26423860}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Apical cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12590146}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12590146}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in brain, liver, lung, and kidney.
CC       In kidney expressed in cortex and inner medulla, in ascending thin
CC       limbs (ATLs) and lower descending thin limbs (DTLs). Primarily
CC       expressed in the proximal tubules of the kidney.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12590146, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26423860}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: After water restriction, up-regulated in inner medulla
CC       ascending thin limbs (ATLs) and lower descending thin limbs.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26423860}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   GENE FAMILY.
RX   PubMed=25053812; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1406073111;
RA   Rautengarten C., Ebert B., Moreno I., Temple H., Herter T., Link B.,
RA   Donas-Cofre D., Moreno A., Saez-Aguayo S., Blanco F., Mortimer J.C.,

RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND
RP   BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES.
RX   PubMed=27381418; DOI=10.1038/ncomms12119;
RA   Rautengarten C., Ebert B., Liu L., Stonebloom S., Smith-Moritz A.M.,
RA   Pauly M., Orellana A., Scheller H.V., Heazlewood J.L.;
RT   "The Arabidopsis Golgi-localized GDP-L-fucose transporter is required
RT   for plant development.";
RL   Nat. Commun. 7:12119-12119(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as the major nucleotide-sugar transporter for the
CC       import of GDP-Fucose into the Golgi lumen. Transports GDP-Fucose
CC       in a strict counter-exchange mode. Is required for proper plant
CC       growth and development (PubMed:27381418). Acts also as a GDP-
CC       mannose transporter that may be involved in the import of GDP-
CC       mannose from the cytoplasm into the Golgi lumen (PubMed:15480787).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15480787, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27381418}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=7 uM for UDP-Fucose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27381418};
CC         Vmax=54 nmol/sec/mg enzyme toward UDP-Fucose
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27381418};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15480787, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27381418}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15480787}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Ubiquitous. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15480787,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27381418}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: RNAi plants display dwarfed phenotype with severe
CC       developmental growth defects. Cell wall composition of the RNAi
CC       plants shows a considerable reduction of the fucose content. GFT1
CC       down-regulation has also an impact on the levels of protein
CC       fucosylation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27381418}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the nucleotide-sugar transporter family.
CC       GDP-Mannose:GMP antiporter (GMA) (TC 2.A.7.13) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar
CC       phosphotransferase system (sugar PTS), a major carbohydrate active
CC       transport system, catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar
CC       substrates concomitantly with their translocation across the cell
CC       membrane. The enzyme II CmtAB PTS system is involved in D-mannitol
CC       transport. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P28008}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: [Protein]-N(pi)-phospho-L-histidine + D-
CC       mannitol(Side 1) = [protein]-L-histidine + D-mannitol 1-
CC       phosphate(Side 2). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P00550,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P28008}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P28008}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00427}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00427}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The EIIC type-2 domain forms the PTS system translocation
CC       channel and contains the specific substrate-binding site.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00427}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PTS EIIB type-2 domain is phosphorylated by phospho-
CC       EIIA on a cysteinyl residue. Then, it transfers the phosphoryl
CC       group to the sugar substrate concomitantly with the sugar uptake
CC       processed by the PTS EIIC type-2 domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00422}.

RP   REVIEW.
RC   STRAIN=cv. Columbia;
RX   PubMed=25988582; DOI=10.1016/j.pbi.2015.04.005;
RA   Eom J.-S., Chen L.-Q., Sosso D., Julius B.T., Lin I.W., Qu X.-Q.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates both low-affinity uptake and efflux of sugar
CC       across the plasma membrane. Can transport glucose, and, to a lower
CC       extent, mannose, fructose and galactose.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107422}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=9 mM for glucose {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107422};
CC         Vmax=51.7 pmol/sec/mg enzyme with glucose as substrate (for
CC         uptake) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107422};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 8.5 for uptake. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107422};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms homooligomers and heterooligomers with SWEET9,
CC       SWEET11, SWEET13, SWEET15, SWEET16 and SWEET17.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24027245}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107422,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24027245}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107422}. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24027245}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Mainly expressed in flowers.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107422}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Slightly induced by the powdery mildew fungus
CC       G.cichoracearum. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107422}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Impaired glucose transport activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107422}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SWEET sugar transporter family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAF87899.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   REVIEW.
RC   STRAIN=cv. Columbia;
RX   PubMed=25988582; DOI=10.1016/j.pbi.2015.04.005;
RA   Eom J.-S., Chen L.-Q., Sosso D., Julius B.T., Lin I.W., Qu X.-Q.,
RA   Braun D.M., Frommer W.B.;
RT   "SWEETs, transporters for intracellular and intercellular sugar
RT   translocation.";
RL   Curr. Opin. Plant Biol. 25:53-62(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates both low-affinity uptake and efflux of sugar
CC       across the plasma membrane. Required, in pollen, for microspore
CC       cell integrity and primexine pattern formation (PubMed:18434608,
CC       PubMed:25988582). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8L9J7,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18434608, ECO:0000303|PubMed:25988582}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms homooligomers and heterooligomers with SWEET4,
CC       SWEET5, SWEET6, SWEET7, SWEET9, SWEET10, SWEET11, SWEET13,
CC       SWEET15, SWEET16 and SWEET17. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24027245}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18434608,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24027245}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18434608}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8LFH5-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8LFH5-2; Sequence=VSP_034712, VSP_034713;
CC         Note=Derived from EST data. No experimental confirmation
CC         available. Not detected in inflorescence (PubMed:18434608).
CC         {ECO:0000305|PubMed:18434608};
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in inflorescences, embryo sacs and
CC       pollen, and at a lower level in stems. Barely detected in roots,
CC       leaves and seedlings. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16299181,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18434608}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed during anther development in
CC       tapetal cells and microsporocytes during meiosis. When the tapetum
CC       degenerates, detected only in pollen grains.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18434608}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Induced by the pathogenic bacteria P.syringae pv.
CC       tomato. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21107422}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Dramatically reduced fertility due to a
CC       postmeiotic rupture of microspores. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18434608}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SWEET sugar transporter family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC       Sequence=BAB10907.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Inorganic phosphate and glucose-6-phosphate antiporter.
CC       May transport cytoplasmic glucose-6-phosphate into the lumen of
CC       the endoplasmic reticulum and translocate inorganic phosphate into
CC       the opposite direction. Independent of a lumenal glucose-6-
CC       phosphatase. May not play a role in homeostatic regulation of
CC       blood glucose levels. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P57057}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by vanadate but not by chlorogenic
CC       acid. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P57057}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P57057}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily.
CC       Organophosphate:Pi antiporter (OPA) (TC 2.A.1.4) family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   GENE FAMILY.
RX   PubMed=25053812; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1406073111;
RA   Rautengarten C., Ebert B., Moreno I., Temple H., Herter T., Link B.,
RA   Donas-Cofre D., Moreno A., Saez-Aguayo S., Blanco F., Mortimer J.C.,
RA   Schultink A., Reiter W.D., Dupree P., Pauly M., Heazlewood J.L.,
RA   Scheller H.V., Orellana A.;
RT   "The Golgi localized bifunctional UDP-rhamnose/UDP-galactose
RT   transporter family of Arabidopsis.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 111:11563-11568(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Phosphoenolpyruvate/phosphate translocator that
CC       transports phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP), 2-phosphoglycerate, 3-
CC       phosphoglycerate and dihydroxyacetone phosphate. Imports PEP to
CC       the chloroplast stroma as one substrate of the shikimate pathway,
CC       from which aromatic amino acids and a variety of secondary
CC       products derive. Required for correct leaf mesophyll cell
CC       development and expression of chlorophyll a/b binding protein 3
CC       (CAB3). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10488230, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14617088,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14617097, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17981875}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Plastid, chloroplast membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in root columella, lateral root cap
CC       and root vasculature tissue. In leaves, highly expressed in xylem
CC       parenchyma cells. In flowers, expressed in sepals, petals,
CC       filaments of the stamens, anthers and stigma.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14617097}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Reticulate leaf phenotype. Reduced number of
CC       leaf palisade mesophyll cells and increased bundle sheath cells.
CC       Small chloroplasts in mesophyll cells. Reduced photosynthetic
CC       electron transport rate. Under-expression of CAB3 protein. Reduced
CC       levels of aromatic amino acids and phenolic compounds derived from
CC       shikimate pathway. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14617088,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14617097}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TPT transporter family. PPT (TC
CC       2.A.7.9) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
